sentence: Share price of KB Home ( KBH ) dived 5% as the company reported disappointing third quarter 2014 results on Wednesday, Sep 24.
The homebuilding company missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate for both revenues and earnings by a significant margin.

KB Home's adjusted earnings of 28 cents per share in the third quarter of fiscal 2014 lagged the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 38 cents by 26% and declined 6.7% from the year-ago earnings of 30 cents per share.
Earnings were hurt by higher selling, general and administrative expense ratio, weak orders and impairment charge for planned future land sale.
Total revenue of $589.2 million in the third quarter missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $640 million by 7.9%.
However, revenues increased 7% from the year-ago quarter as an increase in pricing offset an unexpected decline in number of homes delivered and weak volumes/orders.
In the third quarter of fiscal 2014, homebuilding revenues increased 7.4% year over year to $586.2 million, driven by higher average selling prices.

The number of homes delivered decreased 1.8% from the year-ago quarter to 1,793 homes as deliveries were deferred to the fourth quarter owing to delays in construction and customer mortgage loan closings.

Home deliveries were also delayed due to the impact of the transition from the company's preferred mortgage relationship with Nationstar to a joint venture relationship (Home Community Mortgage ) with the latter.
However, average selling price (ASP) rose 9% year over year to $327,000, driven by a strategic shift in product mix.
With more communities in lucrative submarkets, KB Home shifted its product mix toward higher priced larger homes.
This way the company could cater to high income consumers.
This trend is also reflected in the company's backlog values.
The company's backlog totaled 3,432 homes as of Aug 31, 2014, up 13% year over year.
Potential housing revenues from backlog rose 37% to $1.10 billion owing to higher number of homes in backlog and increased pricing.
At the end of the quarter, the company had 197 active communities, up 5% from the prior-year quarter.
The company opened 29 new communities during the quarter.
KB Homes' order trends started improving in the first half of 2014 on the back of aggressive land investments made by the company in the past quarters.
Net orders rose 5% in the quarter to 1,827 homes driven by the company's higher average community count.
The value of net orders increased 19% to $629.2 million.
However, net orders and the value of net orders witnessed sequential decline of about 20% and 18%, respectively.
The SG&A expense ratio increased 80 bps year over year to 12.4% in the quarter as the prior year quarter results included a benefit from cash-settled equity-based compensation awards.
However, sequentially SG&A expense ratio improved 40 bps.
KB Home intends to deliver 7,200 to 7,400 homes in fiscal 2014.
The company expects community count to increase 15% in the year.
The company expects gross margins to meet the target of 20% in 2014.

Other Stock to Consider

Better-ranked stocks in the building and related sector include PulteGroup, Inc. ( PHM ), Team, Inc. ( TISI ) and The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ), all carrying a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).
